intro: Papaver rhoeas var. bipinnatifidum, commonly known as the double-flowered poppy, is a variant of the common poppy characterized by its deeply lobed, bi- or tri-pinnate petals. It is a herbaceous annual plant native to Europe and parts of Asia, typically growing to a height of 30–60 cm. The flowers, which bloom in early summer, are predominantly red or orange with a distinctive black center. This variety is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and floral arrangements. Its botanical features make it a striking addition to both wild and cultivated landscapes.
